abstract.text: Converts the pixels in a vImage buffer to another format, using the specified converter.

to the flags parameter. If null is passed here and a temporary buffer is needed, the function allocates one on the heap and frees it before returning. The function may run more slowly, because of both the allocation cost and the cost of virtual memory faults to zero-fill pages as they are used.

With an appropriately configured vImage converter, convert the image channels found in
to the image channels found in
. Whenever possible, conversion passes are vectorized and multithreaded to reduce the time and energy cost of the function.
Use
to determine whether a particular conversion can operate in place. For an in-place conversion to work, you must ensure that
and

All scanlines must start at a byte-aligned address. Some formats have 1, 2, 4, or 12 bits per channel/pixel and might not start at a byte-aligned address. A single byte can’t span multiple rows of data.
Some formats, particularly YUV422 and YUV420, and those with a pixel size that’s not evenly divisible by 8 bits, operate in chunks containing multiple pixels. For example, a YCbCr422 chunk may have

in the chunk. The chunk contains two pixels, each with an independent Y (luminance) component, but shared chrominance.  Even though the chunk width is two, it’s still possible for an image to have a width that’s not divisible by two. This means that some part of the chunk on the rightmost edge of the scanline must refer to a nonexistent pixel.

When reading incomplete chunks, vImage touches only the unused parts of the chunk when it knows it to be safe to do so. When writing incomplete chunks, vImage copies the rightmost valid pixel color into the unused part of the chunk. Thus, on reading, the entire chunk doesn’t have to be there, but on writing, it does. Conventions vary among chunk-using imaging pipelines, and this conservative approach should interoperate with most. However, be careful when writing to chunk-based formats (not to be confused with chunky formats, which merely have several channels interleaved) to make sure that the buffer is large enough to tolerate the write policy.  If you’re tiling chunk-based data, be careful not to run tile boundaries through the middle of a chunk.  Chunks are assumed to be indivisible.

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
Constants that specify the contents of vImage buffers.
Learn the fundamentals of the convert-any-to-any function by converting a CMYK image to an RGB image.

doc://com.apple.accelerate/documentation.title: Building a basic image conversion workflow

abstract.text: A flag that disables vImage internal tiling routines.
A flag that returns the minimum temporary buffer size for the operation, given the parameters provided.
The vImage function completed without error.
A flag that sets the behavior to the default.
A flag that prints a debug message if the operation fails.
Converts the pixels in a vImage buffer to another format, using the specified converter.
A description of a conversion from one image format to another.
Creates a vImage converter that converts a Core Graphics-formatted image to a Core Video-formatted image.
Creates a vImage converter that converts a Core Video-formatted image to a Core Graphics-formatted image.
Creates a vImage converter that converts from one vImage Core Graphics image format to another.
Creates a vImage converter to convert from one vImage Core Graphics image format to another, using custom ColorSync transform.
Returns a list of vImage destination buffer channel names, specifying the order of planes.
Returns a list of vImage source buffer channel names, specifying the order of planes.
Determines whether a converter is capable of operating in place.
An image buffer that stores an image’s pixel data, dimensions, and row stride.
A type for image errors.
A type for processing options.
Look up type aliases, data types, and constants the vImage library uses.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A raw pointer for accessing and manipulating untyped data.
